Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 2014 IEEE International Symposium on Workload Characterization (IISWC-2014)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The award supports the attendance of students to the International Symposium on Workload Characterization (IISWC) which is a top-notch technical forum for the presentation of new and exciting advances in the understanding of emerging computer applications and workloads). The conference will be hosted in Raleigh, North Carolina, USA, in October 2014. Students have much to gain from attending IISWC like learning state-of-the-art methodologies, being exposed to novel techniques, and interacting with senior researchers in their chosen area of expertise.

IISWC is a top-tier conference on workload characterization research with a long and successful history. The conference is often used as the primary venue for interaction between academic and industrial researchers and designers. Historically, the conferences have attracted top research papers from both academia and industry, and many innovations published in the proceedings have been influential in the understanding
of emerging applications and computing systems. Increasing the attendance of students in IISWC will expose more students to the exciting developments in the field and in the long run will help to build a broad base of expertise in the field, which will impact both industry and academia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IEEE International Symposium on Workload Characterization (IISWC) is a premier forum for presenting, discussing and debating new and innovative ideas and techniques for the characterization of computing system workloads. This symposium brings together researchers in fields related to processor architecture, compilers, operating systems, and languages. This NSF travel support aims to cover the travel expenses for approximately 20 students from U.S.-based schools. The outcomes of this project are twofold.

This NSF travel support has provided an invaluable opportunity for student training and career development and an avenue to bring women and under-represented students into research. To ensure an equal opportunity for all interested individuals, the travel grant program was advertised on the IISWC 2014 web page, the IISWC 2014 program, and various e-mail lists. The awardee selection process also focused on encouraging a broader body of students to attend the conference and emphasized diversity. While it is important to support presenting authors, it is also valuable to give an opportunity to non-presenting students. This project successfully attracted 6 non-author students and 4 women students out of the 16 awardees to join IISWC 2014. This project provided rigorous student training by going through a formal travel support application process with student CV, estimated cost, and advisor recommendation and requiring each student to attend all sessions at the conference and to submit a summary report after the conference.

The IISWC conference has been strengthened as a result of the greater attendance that this travel support enabled. Further, the solicitation of the travel support application increased the visibility of IISWC in the community of computer system and architecture research. Finally, participation in high-quality conferences such as the IEEE ISWC provided an extremely important part of the students’ educational experience. Most students have stated in their conference summary that IISWC 2014 was a great success with a unique research focus on benchmarking and workload characterization, which other major conferences lack. They also expressed their willing to attend IISWC in future.
